required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Radioprotective Light-weight Caps in the Interventional Cardiology Setting
clinical_study.official_title: Radioprotective Light-weight Caps in the Interventional Cardiology Setting: a Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of the present trial is to compare the radiation attenuation provided by XPF caps (0.5mm lead-equivalent and 0.3mm lead-equivalent) to the standard protection (fabric cap, basically no protection) as measured in % radiation attenuation) during 150 days of fluoroscopy guided cardiology interventions. The second objective is to compare the operator comfort (rated on a visual analog scale) of wearing the XPF protection caps compared to the standard fabric caps.

detailed_description.textblock:
The primary objective of the present trial is to compare the radiation attenuation provided by XPF caps (0.5mm lead-equivalent and 0.3mm lead-equivalent) to the standard protection (fabric cap, basically no protection) as measured in % radiation attenuation) during 150 days of fluoroscopy guided cardiology interventions. The second objective is to compare the operator comfort (rated on a visual analog scale) of wearing the XPF protection caps compared to the standard fabric caps.
For more information please contact Dr. Raul Herrera, MD, Director Baptist Cardiac and Vascular Institute Baptist Hospital of Miami.

primary_outcome.description: The null hypothesis is that the XPF 0.5mm lead-equivalent caps attenuation is equal to the XPF 0.3mm lead-equivalent and standard cap attenuations. The alternative hypothesis is that the XPF 0.5mm lead-equivalent cap attenuation is superior or inferior to the XPF 0.3mm lead-equivalent and standard cap attenuations. The groups will be compared separately and a pooled analysis, comparing XPF 0.5mm and 0.3mm combined vs. standard is also planned.The radiation protection (radiation dose reduction) expressed as a percentage was calculated by subtracting radiation measured underneath the cap from radiation measured outside the cap and then dividing this difference by the product of radiation measured outside the cap multiplied by 100.

primary_outcome.measure: Absolute Radiation Exposure Outside of Cap
primary_outcome.description: The cumulative radiation doses were defined as the summation of all correspondent equivalent doses measured.

secondary_outcome.description: After completion of the last procedure on each day, the operators were asked to rate the comfort of wearing the cap on a scale from 0 (unbearably heavy, badly fitting) to 100 (very light, well fitting).

secondary_outcome.measure: Operator Comfort Assessment Based on Weight
secondary_outcome.description: After completion of the last procedure on each day, the caps worn by the operators were weighed to assess comfort.

arm_group.description: Interventionalist wear a standard fabric cap during fluoroscopy guided interventions.
Interventionalist wear a XPF 0.3mm lead equivalent cap during fluoroscopy guided interventions.
Interventionalist wear a XPF 0.5mm lead equivalent cap during fluoroscopy guided interventions.

intervention.description: Interventionalist wear a XPF 0.5mm lead equivalent cap during fluoroscopy guided interventions. XPF is a trademark of BloXR (Salt lake City, UT) for a new bi-layer (Barium/Bismuth) radiation attenuation material.

Interventionalist wear a XPF 0.3mm lead equivalent cap during fluoroscopy guided interventions. XPF is a trademark of BloXR (Salt lake City, UT) for a new bi-layer (Barium/Bismuth) radiation attenuation material.
Interventionalist wear a standard fabric cap during fluoroscopy guided interventions.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Interventional Cardiologist practicing in Baptist Cardiac & Vascular Institute
- cardiac procedure requiring C-arm fluoroscopy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Interventional Neuroradiologists and Interventional Radiologists will not be included in this study.

overall_official.affiliation: Baptist Hospital of Miami, Miami Cardiac and Vascular Institute

facility.name: Baptist Hospital of Miami, Miami Cardiac and Vascular Institute

results_reference.citation: Uthoff H, Quesada R, Roberts JS, Baumann F, Schernthaner M, Zaremski L, Hajirawala L, Katzen BT, Staub D, Kreusch AS. Radioprotective lightweight caps in the interventional cardiology setting: a randomised controlled trial (PROTECT). EuroIntervention. 2015 May;11(1):53-9. doi: 10.4244/EIJV11I1A9.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Director, Division of Clinical Research & Outcomes

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Patients presenting to the Miami Cardiac and Vascular Institute for Imaging Study/Procedure.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Voluntary patient participation. PI responsible for patient selection.

measure.description: The null hypothesis is that the XPF 0.5mm lead-equivalent caps attenuation is equal to the XPF 0.3mm lead-equivalent and standard cap attenuations. The alternative hypothesis is that the XPF 0.5mm lead-equivalent cap attenuation is superior or inferior to the XPF 0.3mm lead-equivalent and standard cap attenuations. The groups will be compared separately and a pooled analysis, comparing XPF 0.5mm and 0.3mm combined vs. standard is also planned.The radiation protection (radiation dose reduction) expressed as a percentage was calculated by subtracting radiation measured underneath the cap from radiation measured outside the cap and then dividing this difference by the product of radiation measured outside the cap multiplied by 100.
measure.population: Mean Radiation Protection is described under Outcome Measure Data below.

outcome.title: Absolute Radiation Exposure Outside of Cap
outcome.description: The cumulative radiation doses were defined as the summation of all correspondent equivalent doses measured.
outcome.population: The primary objective of the trial is to show how much radiation attenuation is provided by XPF in absolute and relative terms.

group.title: Radiation Exposure Monitored With Standard Caps.
group.description: Operators were randomly assigned to wear standard fabric Caps. Radiation doses were measured by using dosimeters placed outside and underneath the caps.

group.title: Radiation Exposure Monitored With XPF 0.3 mm Caps
group.description: Operators were randomly assigned to wear the 0.3 mm Caps. Radiation doses were measured by using dosimeters placed outside and underneath the caps.

group.title: Radiation Exposure Monitored With XPF 0.5mm Caps
group.description: Operators were randomly assigned to wear lead-equivalent XPF caps. Radiation doses were measured by using dosimeters placed outside and underneath the caps.

measure.title: Absolute Radiation Exposure Outside of Cap
measure.description: The cumulative radiation doses were defined as the summation of all correspondent equivalent doses measured.
measure.population: The primary objective of the trial is to show how much radiation attenuation is provided by XPF in absolute and relative terms.

outcome.title: Operator Comfort Assessment
outcome.description: After completion of the last procedure on each day, the operators were asked to rate the comfort of wearing the cap on a scale from 0 (unbearably heavy, badly fitting) to 100 (very light, well fitting).

group.title: Standard Caps
group.description: Operators were randomly assigned to wear standard fabric Caps. The operator comfort rating on the VAS (score range, 0-100), with higher numbers indicating better comfort, was obtained in all cases and for all operators.

group.title: XPF 0.3 mm
group.description: Operators were randomly assigned to wear XPF 0.3mm Caps. The operator comfort rating on the VAS (score range, 0-100), with higher numbers indicating better comfort, was obtained in all cases and for all operators.

group.title: XPF 0.5 mm
group.description: Operators were randomly assigned to wear XPF 0.5mm Caps. The operator comfort rating on the VAS (score range, 0-100), with higher numbers indicating better comfort, was obtained in all cases and for all operators.

measure.title: Operator Comfort Assessment
measure.description: After completion of the last procedure on each day, the operators were asked to rate the comfort of wearing the cap on a scale from 0 (unbearably heavy, badly fitting) to 100 (very light, well fitting).

outcome.title: Operator Comfort Assessment Based on Weight
outcome.description: After completion of the last procedure on each day, the caps worn by the operators were weighed to assess comfort.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
